inventory.commentary: Could not find examples of drop off with wn sense 4, which I put in sense group 1

sense.name: move to the rear, retreat
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP BACK; DROP BEHIND; DROP OFF
sense.examples: Ralston dropped back to twelfth after stumbling on a rock. She found her companions tedious and dropped behind to avoid conversing with them.

sense.name: diminish or get worse
sense.examples: The number of students enrolled in the class dropped off after the first week. His grades have dropped off since Christmas. The scores dropped away from last year's high.

sense.name: visit informally
sense.examples: I'll drop by tomorrow with the photos. She always drops in at the most inopportune times.

sense.name: give up, abandon
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP BY THE WAYSIDE; DROP OUT
sense.examples: Her profound confidence kept her going when other women would have dropped by the wayside. After the poll results, Wilson dropped out of the election. Even traditional values like quality assurance are dropped by the wayside during this phase. We should not allow visual talent to be dropped by the wayside just because of verbal deficiencies.

sense.name: leave school
sense.examples: Sandra dropped out her sophmore year.

sense.name: leave, unload
sense.examples: I'll drop you off at the corner.

sense.name: fall asleep
sense.examples: He dropped off the minute his head hit the pillow.

sense.name: DROP OPEN: open involuntarily
sense.examples: His jaw dropped open at the sight.

sense.name: DROP DOWN: fall to a lower level
sense.examples: The coach told him to drop down and give him twenty.

sense.name: multiword expression
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP A LINE; DROP ANCHOR; DROP DEAD
sense.examples: Drop me a line when you get to Berlin. The ship dropped anchor in Witma Bay. He dropped dead of a heart attack.
